transcription.text: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid. Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.

work.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
